abstract.p: Benjamin B Ferencz letter on Michael Ignatieff's May 15 article urges powerful nations to give United Nations tools and rules to succeed at peacekeeping

block.p: Michael Ignatieff (''A Bungling U.N. Undermines Itself,'' Op-Ed, May 15) blames United Nations bungling for peacekeeping failures. Permanent members of the Security Council have been reluctant to risk their own troops to maintain world peace. They have failed to create a permanent international military force under United Nations auspices.

Michael Ignatieff (''A Bungling U.N. Undermines Itself,'' Op-Ed, May 15) blames United Nations bungling for peacekeeping failures. Permanent members of the Security Council have been reluctant to risk their own troops to maintain world peace. They have failed to create a permanent international military force under United Nations auspices.

Unilateral and selective use of force without the authorization of the Security Council, even if well intentioned, is no substitute for the rule of law. Let the Security Council lay down clear mandates for lawful humanitarian intervention. Powerful countries must give the United Nations the tools and the rules to do the job.
BENJAMIN B. FERENCZ New Rochelle, N.Y., May 15, 2000
The writer was a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials.
